bboxes.raw_text:
LUSKA, Northern Rhodesia-
African nationalists in Northern
Rhodesia want American Negroes
to quit the United States and re-
turn to 'Mother Africa"


The voice of UNIP. official
magazine of the local National
ist Party. said in recent issue:


American Negroes have COM
pletely neglected to show the
world they are proud Of Mother
Africa"


Saying foreign domination is
being completely wiped out on
the continent, the magazine goes
on:


eve in Africa would like to
see reborn an African nation liv-
ing not in Africa but in the
United States of Africa where
we shall proudly feel sense of
oneness and belonging.


because we would like you
Negroes to share with us in this
sense of belonging we call you
to come back to Mother Africa.
You will be wildly and warmly
welcome in all African states
where you have your true broth
ers."

NEW YORK AL Downing. a
key factor in the Yankee pennant
victory last year as a southpaw
rookie pitcher, signed his 1864
contract last week.


Downing was called up from
Richmond of the International
League on June E and compiled
as 1875 won-lost record for the
Yankees. Downing was believed to
have received a raise from the
major league base pay Of 1000
to about $4,000.


Downing compiled 2.56 earned
run average last year and struck
out III batters in l76 innings. On
eight occasions he struck out 10
or more batters in a single game.

A defense motion for a Super
Tor Court rehearing concerning
felony manslaughter charge
pending against a l6-year-old
girl will be heard at 9 am.
Feb. 10 by Judge William A.
Holohan.


Defense attorney H. B. Dan
iels requested the rehearing in
behalf of Shirley Campbell, l6,
Of 814H S. 10th Ave.


Miss Campbell faces adult
prosecution on a charge that she
fatally stabbed Albert Jacobs
10. of 8l3F S. 10th Ave., in the
neck with a broken bottle at a
party on July l6.


Daniels seeks at the rehearing
to reinstate a court order of Oct.
% in which Judge E. R. Thur
man quashed the manslaughter
charge because the defendant was
not granted a hearing in juvenile
court after the manslaughter
count was filed.


Judge Thurman at a Nov. 81
rehearing requested by the state
reversed his earlier order and
reinstated the charge.


The state argued at that time
that the defendant did receive
the juvenile court hearing I'M
der an original murder charge,
later reduced to manslaughter in
justice of the peace court.

JACKSON, Miss. = Police fired
shotgun blasts to stop demon
stration of Negro students after
stopping a protest march.


Three Negro students. were
treated for buckshot wounds.


Tear gas shells also were
used as students and spectators
left the Jackson State College
gymnasium after a basketball
game.


Rot-trained police sealed off
the Jackson State campus and
also adjoining Campbell College
for Negroes.


The demonstration was the
first serious racial protest here
since last summer when a mora
torium on protests was called
after the assassination Of Negro
civil rights leader Medgar
Evers.


The earlier protest march
came after a white motorist
struck 20-year-old Negro CO.
ed while she was crossing Lunch
Street, a main thoroughfare
which bisects the jackson State
campus.


The driver of the car was given
a ticket for failure to yield to
a pedestrian.

POLICE FIRE
ON NEGROES
AT JACKSON, MISS

Arizona Public Service Com
pany announced that, based on
unaudited figures, earnings per
share of common stock for 1868
increased to $l.4o, compared
with $3.50 for 1862.


John L. Liecty, financial vice
president. pointed out that gains
in revenue, coupled with i'm
provements in operations and in
come tax liability, contributed
to the increase.


Liecty stated that base rev.
enues from regular electric Gus
toners were up 81 per cent,
while those from regular gas Gus
toners were up 60 per cent.
Decreases in bulk irrigation
sales and sales to short-term
industrials were more than off,
set by increases in short-term
sales to other utilities. Total
operating revenues and net in
come reached $ol.8 million and
$l5.2 million. respectively, in
1868.

~ = -. rn~-


JACKSON. Miss. Charles
Evers, NAACP Mississippi field
secretary. denied that he pre-
dicted "open warfare" between
white and Negro extremists If
Byron de la Beckwith were not
convicted. 1E>J v17uoJ sqoot


The statement was attributed to
him in a UPI dispatch carried
by at least one Southern news
paper. m I'M


In an interview with CHS tele-
vision Mr.. Evers stated. ut Is
true that my brother was we'll
loved and respected by the Negro
community here. 1t is also true
that a trial that did not result
in Justice being done would be
most disturbing to them but
there Is no cause to believe that
colored citizens would do any
thing which would bring discredit
upon themselves, their organiza-
ton or the memory. Of their
hero" .. i,aF-r r.


Mr.. Evers said he would have
no comment on the trial at this
time. --...r .r

Flames from an outside trash
pile burned through a window
and into the office of DR.. David
M. Solomon at pa E. Madison.
Firemen said there was a strong
pos sibility the fire was set.

"Sudsing out" underpinnings
after each wearing is a basic re-
quirement for fastidious cleanli-
ness.

because we would like you

where you have your true broth
ers."

to about $4,000.

out III batters in l76 innings. On
eight occasions he struck out 10
or more batters in a single game.
